article.title: Planck intermediate results. LIII. Detection of velocity dispersion from the kinetic Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the top right panel of Figure 1 demonstrate about the 2D-ILC CMB map?
choices: It shows significant tSZ residual effects in the direction of galaxy clusters.
It appears to show substantially reduced tSZ residuals compared to the NILC map.
It reveals a strong excess of power due to Galactic emission.
It highlights a significant residual offset due to dust contamination.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of plotting the profile of the stacked Planck 217-GHz map in Figure 2?
choices: To demonstrate the complete removal of the tSZ signal at 217 GHz.
To illustrate the effectiveness of the 2D-ILC map in removing the kSZ signal.
To provide a baseline reference for comparison with the NILC and 2D-ILC CMB maps.
To showcase the impact of residual dust contamination on the stacked profiles.
The temperature anisotropy of the CMB due to the kinetic Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect.
The spectral energy distribution of the thermal Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect.
The pairwise momentum estimator used for detecting the kSZ effect.
The conversion between flux and temperature for CMB fluctuations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the red vertical dashed line in Figure 9 represent?
choices: The mean value of the rms for 5000 mock catalogues.
The scatter of the 5000 rms values of the random catalogues.
The rms value of the 1526 true MCXC cluster positions.
The level of residual tSZ contamination in the 2D-ILC map.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from Figure 12?
choices: Cluster lensing has a negligible impact on the measured temperature dispersion.
Cluster lensing causes a significant bias in the 2D-ILC map.
The lensing-shifted s² value is consistent with the rms of the random catalogue.
Cluster lensing causes a roughly 0.7σ shift in the width of the histogram.
